posts.name: Discrecy
posts.cooked:
I really appreciate what you do and how much effort you put into keeping our data private. Signal is one of the few apps that I trust, and I‚Äôve recommended it to so many people because of that.

But with the recent AWS outage, I started thinking (and I‚Äôve seen others asking the same thing), why is Signal hosting on Amazon Web Services? I get that everything is encrypted end-to-end, but a lot of people just don‚Äôt trust ‚Äúbig tech‚Äù companies like Amazon when it comes to privacy even if they technically can‚Äôt see our messages. It‚Äôs more about the principle and the feeling of who‚Äôs holding the keys to the infrastructure.

I‚Äôm not trying to attack Signal or tell you how to run things, I just want to understand better:

  • Is Signal planning to move away from AWS or use a more independent hosting setup?
  • How much can AWS actually see (like metadata or traffic patterns)?
  • What are the privacy trade offs (if any) in using their services?

I think it‚Äôd really help if Signal could communicate more about this, because the community seems to be wondering and worrying a bit.

Here is a little story to explain how I feel:
There was once someone who really wanted to protect everyone‚Äôs secrets. They built an unbreakable box that no one could ever open even themselves. But when they needed a place to store it, they gave it to the biggest guy in town the same one known for collecting everyone‚Äôs stuff. The box stayed locked, but people started to ask, Is it really safe there, or just locked in the wrong hands?

Anyway, I‚Äôm just a regular user who cares about privacy and loves what Signal stands for. I hope this doesn‚Äôt come off the wrong way, it‚Äôs just something I think many of us are curious about. Thanks again for all your work and for being one of the few that actually care about our privacy.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Discrecy:

a lot of people just don‚Äôt trust ‚Äúbig tech‚Äù companies like Amazon when it comes to privacy

Signal is designed in such a way that it does not trust the server. Someone a lot smarter than me can explain it better but, to put it simply, there‚Äôs no way for AWS or any other host to see any of your Signal data.

posts.name: Discrecy
posts.cooked:
I know and that exactly what I said above and this is the philosophy of Moxie Marlinespike to secure the information not the computer storing the information (It is how IT Security should be), but here more of fighting against the evil of ‚Äúbig tech‚Äù and the same time using there services and paying them money (to be bigger). Do you see the contradiction?

So the point is about the principle.

posts.name: Michel
posts.cooked:
Discrecy:

I think it‚Äôd really help if Signal could communicate more about this, because the community seems to be wondering and worrying a bit.

They tried to explain the Why? in their blog about costs, search for ‚Äòaws‚Äô here: Signal >> Blog >> Privacy is Priceless, but Signal is Expensive

link_counts.title: Signal >> Blog >> Privacy is Priceless, but Signal is Expensive

posts.cooked:
Signal Messenger

Privacy is Priceless, but Signal is Expensive

Signal is the world‚Äôs most widely used truly private messaging app, and our cryptographic technologies provide extra layers of privacy beyond the Signal app itself. Since launching in 2013, the Signal Protocol‚Äîour end-to-end encryption technology‚Äîhas...

As a small nonprofit organization, we cannot afford to purchase all of the physical computers that are necessary to support everyone who relies on Signal while also placing them in independent data centers around the world. Only a select few of the very largest companies globally are still capable of doing this, which is a hallmark of a troublingly concentrated industry.

link_counts.title: Signal >> Blog >> Privacy is Priceless, but Signal is Expensive

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
this blog post is a somewhat good introduction. it‚Äôs technically about something different (the hosting country, not the hosting company) but the point is the same: if you do everything securely, it doesn‚Äôt really matter where you have your encrypted data, because nobody would be able to read what‚Äôs inside.

Dhole Moments ‚Äì 9 Jul 25

Jurisdiction Is Nearly Irrelevant to the Security of Encrypted Messaging Apps...

Every time I lightly touch on this point, I always get someone who insists on arguing with me about it, so I thought it would be worth making a dedicated, singular-focused blog post about this topi‚Ä¶

link_counts.title: Jurisdiction Is Nearly Irrelevant to the Security of Encrypted Messaging Apps - Dhole Moments

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: It ultimately doesn‚Äôt matter who is hosting Signal, as has been said multiple times above, but it should be stated that there are no services outside of Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud that offer highly-available global infrastructure. Yes, there are European options, but those mostly only service regional needs, and that‚Äôs not conducive to a global service.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Mastodon ‚Äì 27 Oct 25

Meredith Whittaker (@Mer__edith@mastodon.world)

üì£THREAD: It‚Äôs surprising to me that so many people were surprised to learn that Signal runs partly on AWS (something we can do because we use encryption to make sure no one but you‚Äìnot AWS, not Signal, not anyone‚Äìcan access your comms). It‚Äôs also...

Full thread:

It‚Äôs surprising to me that so many people were surprised to learn that Signal runs partly on AWS (something we can do because we use encryption to make sure no one but you‚Äìnot AWS, not Signal, not anyone‚Äìcan access your comms).

It‚Äôs also concerning.

Concerning, bc it indicates that the extent of the concentration of power in the hands of a few hyperscalers is way less widely understood than I‚Äôd assumed. Which bodes poorly for our ability to craft reality-based strategies capable of contesting this concentration & solving the real problem.

The question isn‚Äôt ‚Äúwhy does Signal use AWS?‚Äù It‚Äôs to look at the infrastructural requirements of any global, real-time, mass comms platform and ask how it is that we got to a place where there‚Äôs no realistic alternative to AWS and the other hyperscalers.

Running a low-latency platform for instant comms capable of carrying millions of concurrent audio/video calls requires a pre-built, planet-spanning network of compute, storage and edge presence that requires constant maintenance, significant electricity and persistent attention and monitoring.

Instant messaging demands near-zero latency. Voice and video in particular require complex global signaling & regional relays to manage jitter and packet loss. These are things that AWS, Azure, and GCP provide at global scale that, practically speaking, others (in the western context) don‚Äôt.

This isn‚Äôt ‚Äò‚Äòrenting a server.‚Äô It‚Äôs leasing access to a whole sprawling, capital-intensive, technically-capable system that must be just as available in Cairo as in Capetown, just as functional in Bangkok as Berlin. Particularly given the high stakes use cases of many who rely on Signal.

Such infrastructure costs billions and billions of dollars to provision and maintain, and it‚Äôs highly depreciable. In the case of the hyperscalers, the staggering cost is cross-subsidized by other businesses‚Äìthemselves also massive platforms with significant lockin.

Meaning that infrastructure like AWS is not something that Signal, or almost anyone else, could afford to just ‚Äúspin up.‚Äù Which is why nearly everyone that manages a real-time service‚Äìfrom Signal, to X, to Palantir, to Mastodon‚Äìrely at least in part on services provisioned by these companies.

But even if Signal had the billions needed to recreate AWS, it‚Äôs not just about money. The talent to run these systems is rare & concentrated. The expertise, the tooling, the playbooks, the very language of modern SRE came out of these hyperscalers, and is now synonymous with ‚Äòthe cloud.‚Äô

o, yes, Signal runs on AWS. It also runs on your phone, which runs on iOS (Apple) or Android (Google). And on Dekstop, via Windows (Microsoft). Each of these presents similar dependencies on large entrenched tech companies, and concomitant barriers and risks.

In short, the problem here is not that Signal ‚Äòchose‚Äô to run on AWS. The problem is the concentration of power in the infrastructure space that means there isn‚Äôt really another choice: the entire stack, practically speaking, is owned by 3-4 players

So, Signal does what we can to provide a service w integrity in the concentrated ecosystem we‚Äôre working in. We protect your comms w end-to-end encryption, so that we can use AWS and others as a highway across which to send Signal data in ways that don‚Äôt let AWS, or anyone else, gain access.

To conclude: my silver lining hope is that AWS going down can be a learning moment, in which the risks of concentrating the nervous system of our world in the hands of a few players become very clear. And that this can help us craft ways of undoing this concentration and creating real choice

The Verge ‚Äì 27 Oct 25

‚ÄòThere isn‚Äôt really another choice:‚Äô Signal chief explains why the encrypted...

Signal was just one of many services brought down by the AWS outage.
